Award.AwardTitle: NSF Showcase for DUE Projects at the ACM SIGCSE Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports recipients of the National Science Foundation Division of Undergraduate Education grants to present their research to the wider computer science education community. These presentations take place at the ACM Special Interest Group on Computer Science Education (SIGCSE) Symposium. The showcase has successfully helped the dissemination of research projects in the CE-21, TUES, and other DUE programs directly to thousands of CS educators.

In addition, the showcase holds "office hours" with NSF program officers, providing potential proposal writers an opportunity to gain feedback on their ideas and general guidance regarding the proposal creation and submission process.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to fund a NSF project showcase at the ACM (Association for Computing Machinery) SIGCSE (the Special Interest Group in Computer Science Education) annual conference for four years (2014 through 2018).  This showcase had two primary goals.

The first goal was to allow twenty individuals (or teams) with current and active NSF grants to present their research and results during the conference.  This allowed for dissemination of their work to the wider computer science education community.  Additionally, it allowed the presenters to connect with potential collaborators who could aid their research goals, or individuals who might use their work -- either while said work was being developed or after it was completed.

The second goal was to allow potential grant writers to speak one on one with NSF program officers.  They were able to ask questions about their grant idea, get writing tips, and learn how to better align their idea with the goals of the repsective call for proposals.  Multiple NSF program officers held "office hours" during the conference that attendees signed up for.

Post-conference surveys indicated that the participants felt that the showcase helped them further their research either through through dissemination or by finding collaborators or users.
